ygData.subject: Request: Simple Scenario file for testing purposes.
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi people, I was wondering if you d provide us programmers with a small, simple scenario without too many objects in it to help us conduct initial testing.

From: "Deathifier" <storey@...>

Hi people,
I was wondering if you'd provide us programmers with a small, simple
scenario without too many objects in it to help us conduct initial testing.

It's much easier when you can look at the Hex information in the file and
whats actually being loaded, easier to spot mistakes and track bugs and
stuff :)

I've just finished the majority of the scenario reading code, and the
scenario I picked aparently has 432 objects in it, not something I want to
go through and compare by hand...

Also, is the first character of the Name of an object always NULL if it's
not used?
It doesn't look like it from my debug view, but then I think there's a bug
in there, since I now have a level -17000 object, hmm...
The 'garbage' that fills the other strings looks interesting though, would
it matter if it was a bit cleanner, say just as zero's?  I can certainly
store the garbage chars when I read it in, but they'll be lost during the
write-to-text-file process as they are not dumped out, and when I read it in
I'm likely to run ZeroMemory() over the variable first so any garbage will
be cleared.
Just want to make sure I'm not going to screw anything up, as running an
automatic comparison program over the original scenario file, and one thats
been converted both ways (first to text, then back to scenario) won't work
well for testing it's correctness, since the 'garbage' chars will be
different.

Ah well, hope to have it working within a few days, then maybe I'll work out
a better error handling system, right now it's a 4:1 line ratio for error
handling code : file read code.

Cya's,
Deathifier
*Goes back to looking at the rather amusing attempt of MSVC++ to display
char arrays that don't have a NULL terminator in them, I wish it would only
display the data thats in the actual array - it knows the length...*
